subject: apgov
title: Marbury v. Madison
quickTake: Established the power of judicial review.
corePrompt: Does the Supreme Court have the authority to declare acts of Congress unconstitutional?
answerText: The Supreme Court has the power of judicial review and may declare acts of Congress unconstitutional.
facts: William Marbury was appointed justice of the peace but did not receive his commission.
Marbury sued Secretary of State James Madison.
The Judiciary Act of 1789 expanded the Court’s original jurisdiction.
reasoning: The Constitution is the supreme law of the land.
Any law conflicting with the Constitution is void.
It is the duty of the judiciary to interpret the law.
precedent: Established judicial review.
Strengthened the power of the judicial branch.
whyExam: Foundation of judicial power.
Frequently referenced in separation of powers questions.
whyReal: Allows courts to strike down unconstitutional laws.
Shapes every constitutional case that follows.

subject: apgov
title: McCulloch v. Maryland
quickTake: Congress can create the Bank of the United States, and Maryland cannot tax it.
corePrompt: Does Congress have the power to create a national bank, and can a state tax it?
answerText: Congress has implied powers under the Necessary and Proper Clause to create a national bank, and state taxes that interfere with valid federal action are unconstitutional under the Supremacy Clause.
facts: Congress chartered the Second Bank of the United States.
Maryland passed a tax targeting the bank.
James McCulloch, a bank cashier, refused to pay the tax and was sued by Maryland.
reasoning: The Constitution grants Congress enumerated powers plus implied powers needed to carry them out.
The Necessary and Proper Clause supports means that are useful and appropriate for executing enumerated powers.
States cannot use taxation to control or destroy federal institutions because federal law is supreme.
precedent: Strengthened the idea of implied powers.
Reinforced federal supremacy when state action conflicts with valid federal action.

terms.definition: Powers not explicitly listed but reasonably derived from enumerated powers.
Allows Congress to make laws needed to carry out its listed powers.
Federal law is the supreme law of the land when validly enacted.

whyExam: Common example of implied powers and federal supremacy.
Often used to explain how the national government can expand authority through interpretation.
whyReal: Supports a strong national government in disputes with states.
Used as a foundation for later federal power cases.
leadsTo: Gibbons v. Ogden (1824) for national power in the economy
connectsBack: Constitutional Convention debates over a stronger national government

subject: apgov
title: Gibbons v. Ogden
quickTake: Only Congress can regulate interstate commerce, including navigation.
corePrompt: Can New York grant a monopoly that blocks a federally licensed operator from running steamboats between states?
answerText: The Commerce Clause gives Congress power over interstate commerce, and federal licensing overrides conflicting state laws.
facts: New York granted an exclusive steamboat operating right to Ogden.
Gibbons operated competing steamboats using a federal coastal license.
Ogden sued to stop Gibbons under the New York monopoly.
reasoning: Commerce includes navigation when it crosses state lines.
When Congress acts within its commerce power, conflicting state restrictions are invalid.
The decision favors a single national market over state barriers.
precedent: Expanded the scope of the Commerce Clause.
Limited state-created economic barriers that conflict with federal authority.

terms.definition: Gives Congress power to regulate commerce among the states.
Economic activity that crosses state lines or affects trade between states.

whyExam: Key case for understanding the Commerce Clause and federal supremacy.
Often paired with McCulloch to show early strengthening of national power.
whyReal: Helped create consistent rules for trade across states.
Cited in later debates about federal regulation of the economy.
leadsTo: Later Commerce Clause cases that test the limits of federal regulation
connectsBack: McCulloch v. Maryland (1819) for national supremacy over conflicting state action

subject: apgov
title: Barron v. Baltimore
quickTake: The Bill of Rights originally applied only to the federal government.
corePrompt: Does the Bill of Rights apply to the states?
answerText: The Bill of Rights applies only to the federal government, not the states.
facts: John Barron sued Baltimore after city construction damaged his wharf.
Barron claimed a taking under the Fifth Amendment.
The case questioned whether the Bill of Rights limited state governments.
reasoning: The Constitution was created to limit the national government.
States were not bound by the Bill of Rights unless explicitly stated.
precedent: Established that the Bill of Rights did not apply to the states.
Later overturned through selective incorporation.
whyExam: Sets up the incorporation doctrine.
Frequently paired with Gitlow v. New York.

subject: apgov
title: Gitlow v. New York
quickTake: The First Amendment applies to the states through incorporation.
corePrompt: Does the First Amendment apply to state governments?
answerText: The First Amendment's free speech protections apply to the states through the Fourteenth Amendment.
facts: Benjamin Gitlow was arrested for distributing socialist literature.
New York criminalized advocating government overthrow.
Gitlow argued his First Amendment rights were violated.
reasoning: Freedom of speech is a fundamental liberty.
The Fourteenth Amendment protects fundamental rights from state infringement.
precedent: Established selective incorporation.
Applied First Amendment rights to the states.
whyExam: Foundation of incorporation doctrine.
Frequently paired with Barron v. Baltimore.

subject: apgov

thumbnail.alt: Brown v. Board of Education thumbnail

title: Brown v. Board of Education
quickTake: Segregation in public schools is unconstitutional.
corePrompt: Does racial segregation in public schools violate the Equal Protection Clause?
answerText: Separate educational facilities are inherently unequal and violate the Equal Protection Clause.
facts: African American students were denied access to white public schools.
Segregation was previously allowed under Plessy v. Ferguson.
Plaintiffs argued segregation caused educational harm.
reasoning: Education is fundamental to citizenship.
Segregation creates feelings of inferiority.
Separate facilities are unequal in practice.
precedent: Overturned Plessy v. Ferguson in education.
Laid the groundwork for desegregation.
whyExam: Key Equal Protection case.
Frequently tested in civil rights questions.

subject: apgov
title: United States v. Lopez
quickTake: Congress has limits under the Commerce Clause.
corePrompt: Does Congress have the power to regulate gun possession in school zones under the Commerce Clause?
answerText: Gun possession near schools is not an economic activity that Congress may regulate under the Commerce Clause.
facts: Congress passed the Gun-Free School Zones Act.
A student challenged the law after being charged.
The law did not regulate economic activity.
reasoning: The Commerce Clause has judicially enforceable limits.
Allowing regulation here would give Congress unlimited power.
precedent: First major limit on the Commerce Clause since the New Deal.
Reasserted state authority.
whyExam: Often paired with Gibbons to show expansion vs limitation.
Key modern federalism case.

subject: apgov
title: Engel v. Vitale
quickTake: School-sponsored prayer violates the Establishment Clause.
corePrompt: Can public schools require prayer?
answerText: State-sponsored prayer in public schools violates the Establishment Clause.
facts: New York schools required a non-denominational prayer.
Participation was officially voluntary.
Parents challenged the policy.
reasoning: Government must remain neutral toward religion.
Official prayer endorses religion.
precedent: Applied Establishment Clause to public schools.
Strengthened separation of church and state.
whyExam: Common Establishment Clause case.
Frequently tested in religion questions.

subject: apgov
title: Baker v. Carr
quickTake: Federal courts can hear redistricting cases.
corePrompt: Can courts intervene in state redistricting issues?
answerText: Redistricting is a justiciable issue under the Equal Protection Clause.
facts: Tennessee failed to redraw districts despite population changes.
Urban votes were underrepresented.
Voters challenged the districts.
reasoning: Equal protection requires fair representation.
Courts have authority to hear such cases.
precedent: Established one person, one vote principle.
Expanded judicial role in elections.
whyExam: Foundation of reapportionment cases.
Frequently tested in voting rights questions.

subject: apgov
title: Miranda v. Arizona
quickTake: Police must inform suspects of their rights.
corePrompt: Must suspects be informed of their Fifth Amendment rights?
answerText: Suspects must be informed of their rights before custodial interrogation.
facts: Ernesto Miranda confessed during police interrogation.
He was not informed of his rights.
The confession was used at trial.
reasoning: Custodial interrogation is inherently coercive.
The Fifth Amendment protects against self-incrimination.
precedent: Established Miranda rights.
Strengthened protections for criminal defendants.
whyExam: Key due process case.
Frequently tested in rights of the accused questions.

subject: apgov
title: Mapp v. Ohio
quickTake: Illegally obtained evidence cannot be used in state courts.
corePrompt: Does the exclusionary rule apply to the states?
answerText: The exclusionary rule applies to the states through the Fourteenth Amendment.
facts: Police searched Dollree Mapp’s home without a valid warrant.
Evidence was seized and used to convict her.
Mapp challenged the search as unconstitutional.
reasoning: The Fourth Amendment protects against unreasonable searches and seizures.
Rights would be meaningless without enforcement.
The Fourteenth Amendment applies this protection to the states.
precedent: Applied the exclusionary rule to the states.
Strengthened Fourth Amendment enforcement in state courts.
whyExam: Core Fourth Amendment and incorporation case.
Often paired with other incorporation cases.
whyReal: Shapes how evidence is handled in criminal trials.

subject: apgov
title: Reynolds v. United States
quickTake: Religious belief does not excuse criminal conduct.
corePrompt: Does the Free Exercise Clause protect religious practices that violate criminal law?
answerText: The Free Exercise Clause protects belief, not criminal conduct.
facts: George Reynolds practiced polygamy as part of his religion.
He was convicted under a federal anti-bigamy law.
Reynolds argued the law violated his religious freedom.
reasoning: Allowing religious exemptions to criminal laws would undermine government authority.
Belief is protected, actions are not.

subject: apgov
title: Wisconsin v. Yoder
quickTake: Compulsory education laws cannot violate sincere religious beliefs.
corePrompt: Can states require Amish children to attend school past 8th grade?
answerText: Wisconsin’s compulsory education law violated the Free Exercise Clause.
facts: Amish parents refused to send children to school past age 14.
Wisconsin law required attendance until age 16.
Parents argued this violated their religious beliefs.
reasoning: The law substantially burdened religious practice.
The state lacked a compelling interest.

subject: apgov
title: Schenck v. United States
quickTake: Speech creating a clear and present danger is not protected.
corePrompt: Can speech be limited during wartime?
answerText: Speech posing a clear and present danger is not protected by the First Amendment.
facts: Schenck distributed anti-draft pamphlets during WWI.
He was convicted under the Espionage Act.
He argued his speech was protected.
reasoning: Context matters in evaluating speech.
Speech that threatens national security can be restricted.

subject: apgov
title: Tinker v. Des Moines
quickTake: Students do not lose First Amendment rights at school.
corePrompt: Do students have First Amendment rights in public schools?
answerText: Non-disruptive student expression is protected.
facts: Students wore black armbands to protest the Vietnam War.
Schools banned the armbands.
Students sued for violating free speech rights.
reasoning: Speech cannot be suppressed without evidence of disruption.
Symbolic speech is protected.

subject: apgov

thumbnail.alt: New York Times Co. v. United States thumbnail

title: New York Times Co. v. United States
quickTake: The government usually cannot stop publication in advance; prior restraint is heavily disfavored.
corePrompt: Can the government block a newspaper from publishing classified documents on national security grounds?
answerText: The government did not meet the heavy burden required to justify prior restraint; the newspapers could publish.
facts: The New York Times and other newspapers obtained a classified study about the Vietnam War (the Pentagon Papers).
The federal government sought court orders to stop publication.
The newspapers argued the orders violated the First Amendment.
reasoning: A free press serves as a check on government.
Prior restraint is the most serious and least tolerable infringement on First Amendment rights.
The government bears a heavy burden to justify stopping publication in advance.
precedent: Reinforced strong protection against prior restraint.
Strengthened press freedom in national security contexts.
whyExam: Required case for free press and prior restraint.
Often used to test limits of First Amendment protections.
whyReal: Protects the ability of the press to publish information about government actions.
Shapes modern debates about leaks, classified information, and press freedom.

subject: apgov
title: McDonald v. Chicago
quickTake: The Second Amendment applies to the states.
corePrompt: Does the Second Amendment limit state governments?
answerText: The Second Amendment is incorporated through the Fourteenth Amendment.
facts: Chicago banned handgun possession.
Gun owners challenged the ban.
They argued the Second Amendment applied to states.
reasoning: The right to bear arms is fundamental.
The Fourteenth Amendment applies it to the states.

subject: apgov
title: Gideon v. Wainwright
quickTake: States must provide an attorney to indigent defendants in felony cases.
corePrompt: Must states provide counsel to defendants who cannot afford an attorney?
answerText: The Sixth Amendment right to counsel is a fundamental right and applies to the states through the Fourteenth Amendment; states must provide counsel in felony cases for indigent defendants.
facts: Clarence Gideon was charged with a felony in Florida and could not afford a lawyer.
The trial court refused to appoint counsel because state law only required it in capital cases.
Gideon represented himself, was convicted, and appealed to the Supreme Court.
reasoning: A fair trial requires legal counsel in an adversarial system.
The right to counsel is fundamental to due process.
The Fourteenth Amendment applies this right to the states.
precedent: Overruled Betts v. Brady (1942).
Expanded incorporation of criminal procedure protections.
whyExam: Required case for rights of the accused.
Shows incorporation through the Fourteenth Amendment.
whyReal: Guarantees legal representation for those who cannot afford it.

subject: apgov
title: Roe v. Wade
quickTake: Recognized a constitutional right to privacy that limited state abortion bans.
corePrompt: Does the Constitution protect a right to privacy that limits state restrictions on abortion?
answerText: The Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protects a right to privacy that includes a woman’s decision to have an abortion, though the state may regulate in later stages of pregnancy.
facts: Texas law banned most abortions.
A pregnant plaintiff challenged the law as unconstitutional.
The case raised questions about privacy and state power.
reasoning: The Court recognized privacy protections tied to liberty under the Fourteenth Amendment.
The state has interests in health and potential life that increase over time.
The decision balanced individual liberty and state interests.
precedent: Expanded the Court’s privacy jurisprudence.
Became a major case in debates over substantive due process and judicial policy making.
whyExam: Required case for privacy and due process.
Often used in discussions of civil liberties and the Court’s role.
whyReal: Influenced decades of abortion policy and litigation.
Central to broader debates about privacy and individual rights.

subject: apgov
title: Shaw v. Reno
quickTake: Racial gerrymandering can violate the Equal Protection Clause.
corePrompt: Do oddly shaped districts drawn primarily on race violate the Equal Protection Clause?
answerText: Districts drawn predominantly based on race are subject to strict scrutiny and may violate the Equal Protection Clause if not narrowly tailored to a compelling interest.
facts: North Carolina created a congressional district with an unusual shape.
The district was drawn with race as a major factor.
Voters challenged the map under the Equal Protection Clause.
reasoning: Classifications based on race are inherently suspect.
Using race as the predominant factor triggers strict scrutiny.
Even well-intentioned redistricting must meet constitutional limits.
precedent: Limited race-based districting without strong justification.
Established a framework for racial gerrymandering challenges.
whyExam: Required case on redistricting and equal protection.
Often paired with Baker v. Carr and other voting cases.
whyReal: Shapes how states draw districts after the census.
Affects representation and voting rights litigation.
